awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SII-NRDZ: ASPIRE: Advanced SPectrum Initiative for Research and Experimentation
awd_abstract_narration:
Many activities of modern society and government depend on use of the electromagnetic (radio-frequency) spectrum. Future growth in these activities requires increased use of dynamic spectrum sharing – ways to enable diverse spectrum users to safely operate closer together in space or frequency or to trade spectrum access more rapidly than is possible with traditional spectrum management approaches. The National Science Foundation National Radio Dynamic Zones (SII-NRDZ) program seeks to advance the use of dynamic spectrum sharing through conducting extended field trials of new sharing approaches. The SII-NRDZ program intends to make a future award called the Engineering and Execution Lead (SII-NRDZ-EEL). The SII-NRDZ-EEL will provide the professional engineering and management required for success of SII-NRDZ program field trials.  In this project, the University of Southern California Information Sciences Institute, the University of Utah, and the Idaho National Laboratory collaborate on the initial planning, technical study, regulatory study, and program and outreach interactions needed to prepare a high-quality proposal to serve as the SII-NRDZ-EEL. The project includes a 12-week summer internship program in each of its two years, with students spending 4 weeks in the laboratory of each of the team members.
 
If selected as the SII-NRDZ-EEL, the USCISI-led team envisions drawing on its experience building and operating wired and wireless test facilities to lay the foundation for future wider use of radio dynamic zone spectrum sharing. The team focuses on a collaborative and scientifically based process for spectrum field trials; systematic and objective assessment of proposed spectrum sharing technologies and methodologies; and providing technical and management support that enables coordinated access to multiple radio dynamic zone sites. The team envisions a comprehensive toolkit supporting all stages of the lifecycle of a field trial, including requirements specification, feasibility analysis, spectrum sharing planning, experiment modeling, test design, test execution and analysis. The team will help build a strong dynamic spectrum sharing community by establishing a web based “ASPIRE hub.” The ASPIRE hub will be an entry point for researchers, a site for sharing tools and data that handles compliance issues, and a platform for community engagement. This project initiates progress towards the planned SII-NRDZ-EEL activities by designing a comprehensive process for NRDZ program field trials; curating an initial set of tools for the NRDZ toolkit; leveraging existing research infrastructure and hub-hosting software tools to bootstrap the ASPIRE hub; and fostering active collaboration with other NRDZ program participants and the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
ASPIRE EEL team combined the expertise at three institutions, USC-ISI, INL

and Univ. of Utah, to conduct a series of activities as follows: 

 

• Deep engagements: Continuous and regular interactions with the SII-NRDZ-STUDY teams: 1) understand needs and goals, 2) learn about the current site, applications, and related challenges, 3) provide expertise and share information across the program, 4) distill best practices. Additionally, several of the ASPIRE team engaged actively at the SpectrumWeek 2023 and NRDZ community open meetings (NRDZCOM) by presenting updates, participating on panels, and leading breakout sessions.

 

• NRDZ Toolkit: Created the NRDZ toolkit hub and shared at the NRDZCOM2 meeting. The toolkit, at this stage is a central shareable knowledge base of DSS technology developed by SII-NRDZ-STUDY teams accessible by the spectrum sharing community. 

 

• Site Visits: The ASPIRE team, joined the NSF–organized site visits to SII-NRDZ-STUDY sites. They visited sites over three days, starting at Idaho National Labs in Idaho Falls, followed by the PAWR POWDER testbed at University of Utah, and ending at the Hat Creek Radio Observatory at Redding CA. These visits provided an in-depth understanding of opportunities and challenges of spectrum sharing field trials at these sites and surrounding environments.

 

• Workshop: The ASPIRE team, organized a new IEEE DySPAN 2024 workshop, named FAST: Field Trials for Advanced Spectrum Sharing. This workshop extended the discussion to the large DSS community of experimentalists to cover solutions for systematic and principled long running field trials with technical, economic, and regulatory innovation. This workshop, hosted on May 13th 2024, had nine technical papers presented in two parallel sessions, along with a keynote by Dr John Chapin and a panel that will bring together stakeholders from industry, government, and academia. The panel includes Dr. Martin Weiss (Director, OUSD R&E Future G), Dr. Monisha Ghosh (Professor, University of Notre Dame, SpectrumX Center), Dr. Amit Mukhopadhyay (Spectrum Standardization, Nokia).
